content.text: A service is a modeling of a set of end points. Typically, this is a circuit or some path traversing one or more end points.
A service is a modeling of a set of end points. Typically, this is a circuit or some path traversing one or more end points. A service can represent any arbitrary grouping of end points.

By organizing end points into a service, the system can correlate any associated network alarms into a single service alarm. A service can have performance data. Using BPUAA, you can create service level fault and performance reports.

BPUAA uses the concepts of end point and services to correlate network alarm information to services. The correlation provides a business context to problems when they occur. This allows operations personnel to make resolution decisions based on the importance of services and priority of the affected customers. This correlation is performed in real–time by the server.

A customer object represents the end user of one or more services. In BPUAA a customer can be associated with zero or more services. This association is maintained by the service definition and is modified with the Service editor. If a service is assigned to a customer, the customer’s name and contact information becomes available on the Service Alarm Details page when the service is alarmed. In other words the customer impact of any service alarm becomes part of the alarm record itself.

This allows NOC personnel to quickly determine which of their customers are affected by a service outage or degradation. The relationship between services and customers is one–to–many. A customer may be associated with many services but a service can only be assigned to one customer.

Customer objects may also be associated with special BPUAA user ids. The user id must be created with the user-role: Customer, and the appropriate customer object selected, using the User editor. This creates a customer based user account that may be used by end users to view their services.
BPUAA supports the organization of services into a hierarchy called the Service Containment Model. The model can be used to -

The basic building block of the model is a service’s segment list. A service’s segment list contains all services on which the service depends directly. The listed services are referred to as high-order services.
A service may declare zero, one or more high order services, as shown in figure below. A Segment List is maintained in each and every service; it can be modified with the Services editor.

The terms high–order and low–order are relative. A low–order service may itself be declared in another lower–order service’s segment list, as is the STS–n in the example. The STS is both a high–order and a low–order service. A service’s Segment List contains only direct dependencies.
In figure below, the VT–n segments list would refer to the STS–n but not any of the OC–ns.
When a service is referenced by another service’s Segment list, it is said to contain the referencing service. Unlike the Segment list, the Contained Services list is recursive.

It is important to note that service containment does not result in the propagation of any service alarms from a higher order service to its contained services. Service alarms, suppressed or unsuppressed, are derived solely from network alarms raised against the service’s end points.

Where rings and normal services/ connections are segments of Parent/ Main service,
Parent service availability will be set to
Case A: Atleast one of immediate segment services (both ring and non-ring) is UNAVAILABLE
Case B: No path is found between source and destination Nodes of a Parent Service.
Parent service availability will be set to
Case A: Atleast one of non-ring segment services is AT_RISK and atleast one path is found between source and destination Nodes of a Parent Service.

Case B: If all non-ring segments are AVAILABLE and atleast one of the included services of ring segment is UNAVAILABLE and atleast one path is found between source and destination Nodes of a Parent Service.
All of the non ring segments are AVAILABLE and all ring segments are AVAILABLE.

A connection represents a network connection between two or more network elements in BPUAA.

A connection represents a network connection between two or more network elements in BPUAA. The modeling of a connection is to clearly differentiate between simple connections (between network elements) versus services that impact customers.

Connections can be comprised of only connections, not services; connections can be logical or physical in nature. Services are dependent on connections and may be other services which then cumulatively provide a service hierarchy model for a customer.

Widget repository refers to the techniques used to communicate data or information by encoding it as visual objects (e.g., points, lines or bars) contained in graphics.

Data widgets refers to the techniques used to communicate data or information by encoding it as visual objects (e.g., points, lines or bars) contained in graphics. The goal is to communicate information clearly and efficiently to users. To convey ideas effectively, both aesthetic form and functionality need to go hand in hand, providing insights into a rather sparse and complex data set by communicating its key-aspects in a more intuitive way.

A report is the formatted result of database queries and contains useful data for decision-making and analysis.
A report is the formatted result of database queries and contains useful data for decision-making and analysis.
BPUAA contains a built-in reporting system. This system is a front-end interface that calls or runs back-end database queries that are formatted for easy application usage.
By using BPUAA a user can generate specific reports for the alarms raised with different severity levels in a given period of time (Day, week or Month).

BPUAA generates graphical and textual reports from the Fault and Performance databases. Fault reports generated from event history can include both current un-cleared and cleared events. Performance reports are generated from selected segments of Performance Metric data.

BPUAA maintains a pooled, reusable set of database connections to a remote database. An advance report provides the ability to query a remote database using the pooled database connection. Generated reports can be exported in Comma Separated Value (CSV) file format.
Based on the assigned roles, some users are restricted from accessing some of the pages and functionality. For a detailed description of user roles refer to the User Roles section under Security.

BPUAA can automatically discover nodes upon user initiated discovery action and add them to the discovery table.

BPUAA can automatically discover nodes upon user initiated discovery action and add them to the discovery table. If your network has a large number of nodes supporting standard communication protocols like SNMP and TL1, using discovery can be an efficient way to add them to the network view.

Even though Nodes can be added manually, it may be beneficial to use a discovery task to add even a single node. One of the benefits of discovery is that BPUAA will populate some node properties learned during the discovery process. These are -

The most important of the above properties is the Resource Adapter name. BPUAA will automatically select the correct Resource Adapter based on the Vendor, Product and Version information reported by the node. If the correct Resource Adapter is found, BPUAA will begin monitoring the node immediately. If not, the node is added in the un-managed state.
The discovery table shown below is used to manage the system’s discovered nodes.

Discovery can be performed on a subnetwork, an IP range, Network topology, or an Ethernet Virtual Connection. All of these specifications are, conceptually, reduced to a list of IP addresses. The addresses are then augmented by a port specification, the combination creating a list of agent addresses to try. BPUAA will attempt to discover an agent at each unique agent address.
Clearly the discovery scope can become quite large if IP and port ranges are used. There is no harm in this, but a large scope will extend the duration of the discovery process significantly.
For each agent address the basic procedure of a discovery task is -

header: Example For IPv4/6 Range Calculation and Subnetwork Calculation

content.text: BPUAA supports IP address of format IPv6 -
content.header: Example For IPv4/6 Range Calculation and Subnetwork Calculation
Example For IPv4/6 Range Calculation and Subnetwork Calculation

content.text: IPv6 Format: x:x:x:x:x:x:x:x IPv4-Mapped Ipv6 Format: ::ffff:x.x.x.x Ipv6 Address: 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:6 The same IP can be mentioned as 2607:f0d0:1002:11::6 IPv4-Mapped Ipv6 Address: ::ffff.127.0.0.1 If you select Discovery Type as Nodes by IP Range, then consider the following example for IPv4/6 Range Calculation. Start IPv4/6 address is 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:7 End IPv4/6 address is 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:c The IP addresses that fall in the range are -2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:7 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:8 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:9 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:a 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:b 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:c If you select Discovery Type as Nodes by Subnetwork, then consider the following example for Subnetwork Calculation. IPv4/6 address is 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:7 Subnet Mask is ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:0 The IP addresses fall in the network are -2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:7 2607:f0d0:1002:11:0:0:0:8

The workflow feature is used to automate certain actions that may be applied to Network or Service Alarms. A well designed collection of Workflows can help NOC personnel organize and prioritize incoming alarms, and remove the burden of manually performing common, routine actions.
Some of these actions could be -
A workflow is comprised of three major components -
The input to a workflow is an active network or service alarm. The workflow process examines the alarm, and if it meets user-defined criteria, one or more pre-defined actions are taken.
For a workflow to be initiated it must have a trigger and an action.

The objective of Advanced editor is to facilitate object versioning and offline editing of Workflows. The versioning allows to track all the changes made to the object and revert to any version at any point of time. The Advanced editor enables you to edit the objects in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) mode.

The ideal users of this feature are the ones who use various other tools instead of BPUAA user interface to create Workflows. It is easy to copy some filters/actions from another workflow using the JSON editor. This section describes the procedure to create a workflow in advanced mode.

Merely by creating a Workflow will not make it active to function. A workflow needs to be enabled to be able to function when required. You can also disable one or more Workflows when not being used.

While creating Workflows, you would have created Workflows of the same trigger, and the priority has been given or set to each workflow in the order of creation. The higher the priority value lowers the priority. In other words, if priority=1 then the highest is the priority, higher the value the priority is decreased.
To view the priority of Workflows of the same trigger in increment or decrement order, the Priority column must be added in the Manage Grid Template.
To add the Priority as a column:
You can select the trigger type to Autonomous trigger (Alarm_raise, Alarm_modify, Alarm_clear) based workflows to run sequentially based on the priority order.
To apply the template created in the Manage Grid Template, Click on the listed template.
Once the template is applied, the Priority column gets added, and you can sort it in ascending or descending order.
